author: By Nick Corasaniti and Reid J. Epstein
title: Democrats Brace for a Narrower Path to Challenge New Voting Laws
description: The Supreme Court’s ruling on Thursday involving Arizona voting laws appeared to limit the options for voting rights groups to mount legal challenges to restrictive new measures being passed in Republican-controlled states.
content: Voting rights activists, on the defensive this year in the face of a wave of restrictive new voting laws, grappled on Thursday with new guidance from the Supreme Court signaling that the challenge will be even steeper now for opposing these laws in court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Tour de France Fan Remains in Custody as Race Heads to Mountains
description: The spectator who caused a serious crash on Saturday could still face charges, a French prosecutor said, but the race’s organizers withdrew their lawsuit over the incident.
content: The spectator who accidentally caused a serious crash at the Tour de France last week could face charges despite a decision by the race’s organizers to withdraw their complaint, a prosecutor overseeing the case said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Mess in New York
description: We make sense of the mayoral election.
content: New York City released another round of results in the Democratic mayoral primary — and city officials insist that they’re accurate this time. They say they have resolved the “discrepancy” that caused them to report inaccurate results on Tuesday from their new ranked-choice voting system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Israel’s New Leaders Tilt Right With Settler Deal, Hinting at Approach
description: Prime Minister Naftali Bennett’s decision about an unauthorized settlement has provided an early idea of how he hopes to manage his unlikely coalition.
content: JERUSALEM — Not a lot binds the new Israeli government. It’s an unwieldy and incoherent coalition of right-wingers, leftists, centrists and Islamists that many fear won’t survive more than a few months, let alone years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Sophie Kasakove and Emily Cochrane
title: Biden meets with families of victims in Surfside: ‘We’re here for you as one nation.’
description: President Biden on Thursday offered impassioned remarks in a hotel ballroom filled with the families of some of those who died or remain missing.
content: SURFSIDE, Fla. — President Biden on Thursday offered impassioned remarks in a hotel ballroom filled with the families of some of those who died or remain missing under the rubble of a collapsed condominium building, according to White House officials and those in the room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Simonson
title: The Women Left Out of the History of Cocktails
description: Nicola Nice wants to set the (overwhelmingly male) record of drinks writing straight.
content: Cocktail history — a relatively new pursuit — tends to dwell on ancient bar manuals from the 19th and early 20th centuries, largely the works of white, male heralded bartenders like Harry Johnson, William Boothby and Jerry Thomas. The books deal with the kind of drinks that were served in taverns, where women were long not permitted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: ‘The One and Only Dick Gregory’ Review: A Peek at a Comic Legend
description: The documentary examines the many lives of the stand-up and activist who inspired a generation of performers.
content: In a remarkable article from October 1960, Ebony magazine asked why there were no Black stars in comedy, blaming racist double standards held by audiences and television bookers as well as a new sensitivity (the term “politically correct” had not been coined) that wouldn’t tolerate performers trafficking in stereotypes from the minstrel era. Three months later, Dick Gregory, mentioned briefly as a “newcomer,” made the question irrelevant in one night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag
title: Office Vacancies Soar in New York, a Dire Sign for the City’s Recovery
description: Nearly 19 percent of all office space in Manhattan has no tenants — the highest on record — as companies shed leases and embrace remote work.
content: Even as New York City reopens and pursues a long road to economic recovery, the pandemic’s lasting legacy of a changing workplace is emerging as a major obstacle to the revival of the vital commercial districts that help fuel the city’s economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Tax charges against the Trump Organization.
content: The Trump Organization, the family real estate business that catapulted Donald Trump to fame, was charged Thursday in a 15-year tax fraud scheme. The charges open up an aggressive new phase in a long-running criminal investigation into the former president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yi-Zheng Lian
title: The Chinese Communist Party Is 100. It’s Not Going Anywhere.
description: The country’s Communist Party rule is stronger than ever.
content: On July 1, the Chinese Communist Party celebrates its centenary. For those in the West banking on its demise, they’re sorely mistaken. Because while the party may have committed some significant missteps throughout its rule, it is still a formidable force that will remain a threat to the United States and Western allies for years to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman, Jim Tankersley and Eshe Nelson
title: U.S. Proposal for 15% Global Minimum Tax Wins Support From 130 Countries
description: A 15 percent minimum tax rate would generate $150 billion in additional tax revenue each year, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said.
content: PARIS — An effort to push the most sweeping changes to the global tax system in a century gained significant momentum on Thursday when 130 nations agreed to a blueprint in which multinational corporations would pay an appropriate share of tax wherever they operate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelia Herrera
title: ‘No. 7 Cherry Lane’ Review: A Heady Daydream in 1967 Hong Kong
description: This nostalgic animated film follows a taboo love triangle.
content: As sumptuous as it is odd, “No. 7 Cherry Lane” is an exercise in harnessing nostalgia for innovation. The first animated film from the director Yonfan is a deeply eccentric chronicle of a forbidden affair in 1960s Hong Kong, as the spirit of Mao Zedong’s anti-imperialist, communist revolution arrives in what was still a British colony. Fan Ziming, a beguiling English literature student, becomes embroiled in a knotty love triangle between Mrs. Yu, a divorced Taiwanese exile and former revolutionary who now deals in luxury goods, and her daughter Meiling, a nubile 18-year-old student taking English lessons from Ziming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock and Muktita Suhartono
title: Indonesia announces restrictions for two major islands as the Delta variant spreads.
description: Indonesia’s president, Joko Widodo, announced new restrictions on Thursday for parts of Java and Bali islands to contain the rapidly spreading Delta variant, including closing mosques, schools, shopping malls and sports facilities.
content: Indonesia’s president, Joko Widodo, announced new restrictions on Thursday for parts of Java and Bali islands to contain the rapidly spreading Delta variant, including closing mosques, schools, shopping malls and sports facilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julianne McShane
title: Cherry Grove, Where Gay New Yorkers Became ‘Their Real Selves’
description: In the 1950s, the Fire Island hamlet was a refuge for gay men and lesbians. Dozens of enlarged photos from the era are now on view outside the New-York Historical Society.
content: In the decades before the Stonewall uprising in 1969, an L.G.B.T.Q. community took shape among New Yorkers on a remote Fire Island hamlet known as Cherry Grove.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lawrence Ulrich
title: Automania at MoMA Balances Celebration and Criticism of Cars
description: The exhibition opens on July Fourth, a holiday that has come to symbolize motorized freedom and parade-queen convertibles.
content: For many Americans, cars became a lifeline and refuge during the pandemic, even as newly sparkling air over locked-down cities highlighted their darker side. Soul-searching over commuting and climate change was balanced by hope that cars might clean up their act via electricity, and allow new generations to fall for their beauty and ingenuity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: California finally has a date for Gov. Gavin Newsom’s recall election. It’s Sept. 14.
description: The date, just 75 days away, is the soonest that county officials said they could manage to pull together a special election.
content: The Republican-led, pandemic-fueled campaign to recall Gov. Gavin Newsom of California got an official election date on Thursday, as the state’s lieutenant governor announced that voters would head to the polls on the issue on Sept. 14.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia and Stacy Cowley
title: Should ‘Bachelor’ Stars Have Received P.P.P. Loans?
description: News that several cast members from the franchise applied for and received federal loans during the pandemic left many fans confused.
content: Several contestants from “The Bachelor” and “The Bachelorette” were asked this week to explain to their fans why they applied for government loans during the Covid-19 pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘The Phantom’ Review: The Death Penalty for a Doppelgänger
description: This documentary examines the circumstances of a 1983 killing in Texas, for which it contends the wrong man was convicted and executed.
content: “The Phantom,” a documentary from Patrick Forbes, examines a case that in recent years has been cited as an example of a likely wrongful conviction that ended in the death penalty. Carlos DeLuna was executed in Texas in 1989 for the murder of a Corpus Christi gas station convenience store clerk. At his trial, he implicated another man, Carlos Hernandez. The prosecution dismissed Hernandez as a phantom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: How to Destroy Truth
description: Americans don’t see the same facts. The real problem is we’ve lost the thread of a common story.
content: Great nations thrive by constantly refreshing two great reservoirs of knowledge. The first contains the knowledge from the stories we tell about ourselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric J. Topol
title: It’s Time for the F.D.A. to Fully Approve the mRNA Vaccines
description: The Pfizer and Moderna vaccines are safe and effective. Full approval from the F.D.A. will  help stop the spread of Covid-19.
content: Here’s a paradox: A new drug for Alzheimer’s disease, aducanumab, gets approved by the Food and Drug Administration through an accelerated process without sufficient data, although there was limited evidence that it works, leading three advisory board members to resign in protest. Meanwhile, mRNA coronavirus vaccines are not yet fully licensed despite massive evidence of their benefits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: The Conductor Transforming Period Performance
description: Mahler, Stravinsky, Debussy and more: François-Xavier Roth and his ensemble, Les Siècles, are pushing historically informed practice into the 20th century.
content: Think of the “period” or historically informed performance movement, and the mind probably turns to Monteverdi, Bach, Handel. The first advocates for performances on original instruments — post-World War II insurgents like Nikolaus Harnoncourt — concentrated their initial work on the Baroque and then Classical repertories, the music in which their findings were most audibly different compared with then-standard practices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘Long Story Short’ Review: Fast Forward to the End
description: After his wedding night, a workaholic gets cursed with previewing how his life will turn out, one year at a time.
content: The British TV comedy “Spaced” had a recurring bit where Simon Pegg would half-apologetically remind his chatty friend to hurry up her story: “Skip to the end?” The same urge came to mind while watching the Australian romantic comedy “Long Story Short,” which is like a recurring bit at feature length.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Digital vaccination cards go into effect in Europe, with some turbulence.
description: “This can only work for travelers if member states implement it in a harmonized way,” said an official representing Europe’s largest air carriers.
content: Digital Covid-19 certificates aimed at facilitating free movement in the European Union came into force across the bloc on Thursday, a long-awaited milestone for countries hoping to boost their ailing tourism industries — but also a point of friction over the number of vaccines that do not qualify.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess, William K. Rashbaum and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Trump Organization Is Charged With Running 15-Year Employee Tax Scheme
description: The company was accused of helping its executives evade taxes on compensation by hiding luxury perks and bonuses.
content: The Trump Organization, the real estate business that catapulted Donald J. Trump to tabloid fame, television riches and ultimately the White House, was charged Thursday with running a 15-year scheme to help its executives evade taxes by compensating them with fringe benefits that were hidden from the authorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard L. Hasen
title: The Supreme Court Is Putting Democracy at Risk
description: After Thursday's rulings, there are fewer and fewer tools with which to fight voter suppression.
content: In two disturbing rulings closing out the Supreme Court’s term, the court’s six-justice conservative majority, over the loud protests of its three-liberal minority, has shown itself hostile to American democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Crowds for European Championship soccer games are driving infections, the W.H.O. says.
description: Fans have been amassing in stadiums, pubs and bars to watch the tournament.
content: Crowds gathering in stadiums, pubs and bars to watch the European Championship soccer games have driven a rise in coronavirus cases across Europe, the World Health Organization said on Thursday, raising concerns about another virus wave  even though vaccination campaigns have made progress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Randi Hutter Epstein
title: The Maps Our Brains Create
description: In “Brainscapes,” Rebecca Schwarzlose lays out the ways our brains let us take in information through a process of intricate “mapping.”
content: BRAINSCAPESThe Warped, Wondrous Maps Written in Your Brain — and How They Guide YouBy Rebecca Schwarzlose
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Iman Stevenson
title: What Happens to the ‘Weed Spot’ Now That Weed Is Legal?
description: New Yorkers on not having to sneak off to smoke marijuana.
content: When recreational marijuana was legalized in New York State in March, much of the change was not immediate. But there was one instantly observable difference: While it is not yet legal to sell or buy marijuana in New York, smoking a joint on the street is not a crime anymore. As long as they observe the same restrictions as on cigarettes, smokers can pretty much spark up where they like.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo
title: Safety First, ‘I Do’s’ Second
description: With the increased demand for in-person celebrations, many wedding officiants have added pandemic safety measures to their ceremony prep.
content: For the past year, whenever Aretha Gaskin, a certified civil celebrant in Plainfield, N.J., leaves her home to officiate a wedding, she always makes sure she has more than enough personal protective equipment with her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Robert Sacchi, Who Played Bogart Again and Again, Dies at 89
description: He was a hard-working actor and not merely a doppelgänger. But his claim to fame on film, TV and the stage was that he looked like Bogie.
content: Lon Chaney was immortalized in a 1957 film as the “Man of a Thousand Faces.” Robert Sacchi could capitalize on only one: his conspicuous resemblance to Humphrey Bogart. He played it for all it was worth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Agha Shahid Ali and Reginald Dwayne Betts
title: Poem: Tonight
description: The ghazal is an M.C.’s form: repeating words, a rhyme scheme and self-referential. The good ones become like a prayer.
content: The ghazal is an M.C.’s form: repeating words, a rhyme scheme, the self-referential last line that signals the end of the bars. When done right, every single line is a prayer. I learned the form from Shahid, when I was in prison and he was already living only in verse. I’d long been telling men to call me by the name of a man I’d never met, already near begging that “G-d, limit these punishments, there’s still Judgment Day/I’m a mere sinner, I’m no infidel tonight.” Selected by Reginald Dwayne Betts
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: The I.R.S. had a backlog of 35 million returns by the end of the tax season.
description: The backlog means that millions of Americans could still be waiting for their refunds.
content: Millions of tax returns are still awaiting processing by the Internal Revenue Service, which has faced a far bigger backlog than in years past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holland Cotter
title: In Maya Lin’s ‘Ghost Forest,’ the Trees Are Talking Back
description: The installation in the heart of Madison Square Park is the artist’s memorial to another war — the one against nature.
content: On a sultry summer day the trees across the street from my Bronx apartment are deep in conversation. Trees are, science tells us, social beings and do some of the same things we humans do, at least when we’re acting our best. They trade tips about health, news about weather. They nourish, and protect, and support each other. They support fellow beings too: birds, insects, us. They live sane lives. They generate excellent karma.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: There’s a chill show for preschoolers and a jewelry-making competition series. Or is it just time to watch “Hannibal”?
content: Every Monday and Friday, Margaret offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley and Julia Jacobs
title: Bill Cosby, Free but Not Exonerated, Faces an Uncertain Future
description: Though his conviction was overturned, and his team is discussing future work, experts say it’s not likely the ruling will change the public perception of the former star.
content: Since Bill Cosby left prison this week after three years of incarceration, flashing a defiant V-sign as he returned a free man to his home in the suburbs of Philadelphia, the talk of his inner circle has been celebratory, as those close to him described his first meal of fish and pizza and his determination to rehabilitate his legacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Greg Noll, Surfing Superstar Who Tackled the Big Waves, Dies at 84
description: Known as ‘Da Bull,’ he caught waves in Hawaii, California, Australia and Mexico. One expert said he “could be the Babe Ruth of surfing.”
content: Greg Noll, a fearless surfer and a superstar in his sport who in the 1960s tackled stunningly big waves in Hawaii, died on Monday in Crescent City, Calif., about 20 miles south of Oregon. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Biden’s Chief of Staff Is Worried About ‘Everything.’ Except the Midterms.
description: Ron Klain discusses the infrastructure bill, the White House pandemic response and why he’ll “let Republicans deal with Donald Trump.”
content: As the White House chief of staff, Ron Klain helps determine how the president spends scarce resources like time and political capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill P. Capuzzo and Anne Mancuso
title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: This week’s properties are in Ardsley, N.Y., and Saddle River, N.J.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: Portugal, where the Delta variant is spreading, reintroduces curfews in dozens of cities and towns.
description: Among the 45 municipalities that will have a curfew from 11 p.m. to 5 a.m. are the cities of Lisbon and Porto, and the tourism hub of Albufeira.
content: Portugal’s government on Thursday announced that it would reintroduce nighttime curfews in municipalities where the coronavirus case rate has risen fastest — including some of its tourism hubs — as it struggles to cope with the spread of the Delta variant.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually or in person in New York City.
content: Have you ever wondered what goes inside the mind of marathon runners during the 26.2 miles it takes to reach the finish line? If so, the writer Melanie Jones grants you access to the thoughts of a first-time runner in “Endure.” The site-specific performance in Central Park has audience members wear audio devices as they trek three miles (at their own pace) along with a marathon runner (Casey Howes or Mary Cavett) and listen to their inner monologue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy Tarng
title: Lincoln Center Names Its First Poet in Residence
description: Mahogany Browne, the author of “Black Girl Magic” and “Chlorine Sky,” will develop in-person and virtual programming from July to September at the performing-arts center.
content: Lincoln Center on Thursday named Mahogany L. Browne its first ever poet in residence, part of its initiative to use its outdoor spaces as New York emerges from pandemic lockdowns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martha Schwendener
title: Sculpture Transplanted to the Gardens
description: These spaces nudge you toward unexpected art surprises and offer vistas of healing and history.
content: Outdoor sculptures provide some of our most accessible encounters with art, and that’s even truer this summer for art viewers who are still hesitant to re-enter galleries and museums, and for those seeking a respite of healing and history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Scenes from an Empty Church’ Review: Cloistered Filmmaking
description: This film, proudly shot and set during the pandemic, stars Kevin Corrigan and Thomas Jay Ryan as priests with different perspectives.
content: “Scenes From an Empty Church” stars three actors — Kevin Corrigan, Thomas Jay Ryan and Max Casella — who emerged as scene-stealers in the 1990s. But watching this proudly pandemic-shot and -set feature from Onur Tukel is like being returned to the locked-down days of 2020. In a decade, the film will serve as a time capsule. But right now, it feels redundant: a dramatization of arguments (about masks, the pandemic’s effects on New York and the value of applauding first-responders at 7 p.m.) that have circulated for too long.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lena Wilson
title: ‘The Forever Purge’ Review: Anarchy Ever After
description: This newest installment in the dystopian franchise, set in a Texan town, pits white supremacists against immigrants and their allies.
content: James DeMonaco’s scripts for “The Purge” play out like drafts from the edgiest guy in your Intro to Creative Writing class. He asks us to imagine America at its hypothetical worst: The government has instituted an annual daylong crime spree called the Purge, and protagonists must fight their way through the waves of rabid murderers they once called neighbors. They’re the sort of plots that only hold up if you buy the misanthropic thesis of something like “Joker,” but DeMonaco likes to throw a few hot political topics into each script to keep things fresh. “The Forever Purge,” directed by Everardo Valerio Gout, tries to criticize American racism against Mexicans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: Your Next Lesson: Rosé From the Dark Side
description: Not all rosés are meant to be pale, even though they are fashionable. Different techniques and traditions produce rosés of many hues.
content: The world seems to have embraced the notion that rosé is meant to wear only the palest shade of pink.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.J. Goldmann
title: Generational Divides Emerge Onstage in Germany
description: At newly reopened playhouses, once-legendary and younger directors take very different approaches to their mammoth productions.
content: BERLIN — Theatergoers know what to expect from a Frank Castorf production. The director, who helped shape the last 30 years of German theater, favors a deconstructive approach to the classics, reams of dialogue barked like manifestoes and manic performances over a marathon running time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker and Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura
title: Infighting and Poor Planning Leave Condo Sites in Disrepair
description: Under pressure to keep costs down, many condo boards around the country have little money set aside for big repairs like the ones needed in Surfside, Fla. Some are looking to force a change.
content: For years before the partial collapse of the Champlain Towers South complex near Miami, the condo board wrestled with how to come up with the $15 million needed to fix the building’s dilapidated roof, a poorly designed pool deck and crumbling support columns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Day, Samantha Stark and Joe Coscarelli
title: Company Set to Manage Britney Spears’s Estate Asks to Withdraw
description: Bessemer Trust, a professional wealth management firm, said in its filing that it had not known of Ms. Spears’s objection to the conservatorship that governs her life.
content: The wealth management firm that was set to take over as the co-conservator of Britney Spears’s estate, alongside her father, has requested to resign from the arrangement, according to a document filed in court on Thursday, throwing her conservatorship into greater turmoil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Mimi Stern-Wolfe, Presenter of Socially Conscious Concerts, Dies at 84
description: The range of programs she staged on the Lower East Side and in nearby neighborhoods included an annual concert devoted to composers lost to AIDS.
content: Mimi Stern-Wolfe, a pianist and conductor who specialized in music programs with a social-justice or political theme, most notably an annual concert that featured music of composers lost to AIDS, died on June 21 at a care center in Manhattan. She was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb and Marc Stein
title: The N.B.A. Champion May Be the Last Team Standing
description: Injuries to stars have dominated and reshaped the playoffs, raising questions about the legacy of the team that wins it all.
content: The Milwaukee Bucks were in the midst of a comeback on Tuesday against the Atlanta Hawks, who were without their best player, Trae Young. With the Bucks up by two games to one in the best-of-seven Eastern Conference finals series, a win would have put the franchise on the brink of making its first N.B.A. finals since 1974.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Bruce Springsteen, Jennifer Hudson Set for Central Park ‘Homecoming’
description: Paul Simon will also perform at this summer’s concert on the Great Lawn as part of a weeklong celebration of the city’s reopening.
content: Bruce Springsteen! Jennifer Hudson! Paul Simon!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Eileen Sullivan
title: Homeland Security Watchdog Delayed Inquiry, Complaint Says
description: The department’s inspector general delayed looking into a retaliation complaint by a former intelligence chief until after the 2020 election, according to officials and a whistle-blower.
content: The Department of Homeland Security’s inspector general blocked an inquiry into whether senior agency officials demoted an employee who criticized the Trump administration, according to people familiar with the matter and a whistle-blower complaint obtained by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Britney Spears’s case leads 2 senators to question the country’s conservatorship systems.
description: The move could signal the beginning of a legislative effort to overhaul the system.
content: Democratic Senators Elizabeth Warren and Bob Casey are calling on federal agencies to increase oversight of the country’s conservatorship systems, following testimony from the pop star Britney Spears that she had been abused under her conservatorship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Why Didn’t My Friend Tell Me About Her Cancer Diagnosis?
description: A reader wonders how to be a supportive friend without transgressing privacy boundaries.
content: A friend of mine was recently diagnosed with ovarian cancer. The problem: She hasn’t told me. (I overheard her husband talking about it: Her illness was discovered during routine medical tests. She was having a hard time getting pregnant — which she also didn’t tell me.) I thought we were close, but I guess we’re not. Her decision to exclude me from these issues in her life hurts me and puts me in an awkward situation. What can I say if I’m not supposed to know about these big challenges she’s facing? I’m not sure how to handle this. Advice, please?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: What to Know About the Vote Tally Fiasco
description: A revised unofficial count of ranked-choice voting results suggested a tight race among the top three Democratic candidates for mayor.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Robinhood Looks Beyond Its Big Fine
description: The $70 million punishment clears the deck for the trading app’s I.P.O.
content: Robinhood racked up another big fine yesterday, this time from the financial industry regulator known as FINRA. It’s the latest blow to the online brokerage, which has faced a series of accusations of misleading and marooning customers. But the company sees an upside to its latest legal run-in, too: It believes it has resolved lingering issues enough to move forward with its long-anticipated I.P.O.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Time to increase oil production? OPEC and its allies are unable to decide.
description: For more than a year, OPEC Plus has kept a tight grip on oil production, helping to lift prices by around 85 percent since November.
content: Officials from OPEC, Russia and their allies failed to reach agreement on Thursday on whether to ease the output quotas that have helped drive up oil prices to their highest levels since 2018. On Thursday, the oil ministers met by videoconference but were unable to reach a decision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sergio Olmos, Winston Choi-Schagrin and Shawn Hubler
title: Heat-Related Death Toll Climbs to Nearly 100 in Washington State and Oregon
description: The heat wave in parts of the Pacific Northwest played a role in the deaths of dozens of people, some of whom lived alone.
content: PORTLAND, Ore. — The heat took Sebastian Francisco Perez, 38, as the Guatemalan-born farmworker moved irrigation lines in a field in Marion County, Ore., on Saturday in record temperatures that soared to 104 degrees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: After Years of Heartache, the Ball Is Finally Bouncing the Suns’ Way
description: Phoenix is the first team to the make the Finals after missing the playoffs for 10 straight seasons.
content: Chris Paul was on the floor for only four of six games in the Western Conference finals, then revealed after the game of his life that he had a new wrist injury. Devin Booker reluctantly wore a plastic face shield over his broken nose for three games until he finally ditched it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: Robinhood Reveals Rising Revenue and a $1.4 Billion Loss
description: The stock-trading app unveiled its initial public offering prospectus on Thursday, pulling back the curtain on its financial performance for the first time.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Robinhood, the stock-trading app that grew in popularity and notoriety during the pandemic, revealed skyrocketing revenue and a loss of more than $1.4 billion in the first three months of this year, as it took a key step on Thursday toward one of the year’s most anticipated initial public offerings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: College Athletes Score, Cutting Deals as a New Marketplace Is Born
description: From hurdlers to quarterbacks, students signed contracts and began to pull in some of the millions that could be made this year alone.
content: SOUTH MIAMI HEIGHTS, Fla. — The inevitable overture came while Rayniah Jones was watching “Dance Moms.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Amazon, HBO, Hulu and More in July
description: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to their libraries. Here are our picks for some of July’s most promising new titles.
content: (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our twice-weekly Watching newsletter here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Here’s How Biden Aims to Increase Electric Car Sales
description: The president wants to use pollution rules to rapidly lift sales, but there are hurdles ahead.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden has a two-step strategy to cut tailpipe emissions, the nation’s largest source of greenhouse gases: First, restore the standards to roughly the level set by President Barack Obama. Then, tighten them even further, with an aim of making the electric car the dominant vehicle sold in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: In the Male World of Whiskey, More Women Are Calling the Shots
description: Though sexism is still rampant, a number of women are now distilling, blending and reshaping the business in their image.
content: In 2018, the three founders of Milam & Greene, a distillery in Blanco, Texas, made their first trip to the San Antonio Cocktail Conference, one of the state’s largest gatherings of bartenders, distillers and their legions of fans. They were excited to introduce their new whiskey, until they found their assigned table — stuck in a corner, far from the action.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim
title: Louis Andriessen, Lionized Composer With Radical Roots, Dies at 82
description: After challenging the Dutch musical establishment as a young man, he went on to write a series of large and loud symphonic works that grappled with big ideas.
content: Louis Andriessen, who as a young iconoclast disrupted the Dutch classical music scene before becoming one of Europe’s most important postwar composers with a series of large-scale, often brash works, died on Thursday in Weesp, the Netherlands. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: At Wimbledon, Roger Federer Is Staying Firmly in the Moment
description: A straight-sets victory over Richard Gasquet on Thursday showed the eight-time champion at ease with whatever the tournament brings. And in the moment, anything feels possible.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — Wimbledon runs on nostalgia, from the grass courts and the all-white clothing rule to the neckties in the clubhouse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: House, Setting a Marker for Talks, Passes $715 Billion Infrastructure Bill
description: House Democrats loaded their infrastructure measure with climate change spending, staking out a contrast with the Senate’s bipartisan bill that President Biden has embraced.
content: WASHINGTON — The House on Thursday laid down its marker for this month’s infrastructure negotiations, approving a five-year, $715 billion transportation and drinking water bill that would do more to combat climate change than the Senate’s bipartisan measure embraced by President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘The God Committee’ Review: At a Hospital, Judgment Day
description: In this drama starring Kelsey Grammer and Julia Stiles as cardiovascular surgeons, doctors have one hour to choose a heart transplant recipient.
content: “The God Committee” ostensibly ponders the ethical compromises involved in choosing organ transplant recipients, but it mostly illustrates the dangers of facile twists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Backs Donor Privacy for California Charities
description: The 6-to-3 decision held that a state requirement infringed on the First Amendment. The court’s liberal members suggested it could erode disclosure laws for political campaigns.
content: The Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that California may not require charities soliciting contributions in the state to report the identities of their major donors.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A New Era in College Sports
description: For more than a century, the N.C.A.A. banned student-athletes from earning money. That is about to change.
content: Throughout its 115-year history, the N.C.A.A.’s bedrock principle has been that student-athletes should be amateurs and not allowed to profit off their fame.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: Meghan McCain says she’s leaving ‘The View.’
description: After a sometimes stormy four-year run, the show’s conservative voice announces her departure.
content: Meghan McCain will leave “The View” at the end of July, the co-host said on Thursday at the beginning of the popular daytime show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Unveiling of Diana Statue Reunites William and Harry, Briefly
description: The estranged princes put aside their differences for a ceremony at Kensington Palace in London on what would have been their mother’s 60th birthday.
content: LONDON — Bonded by childhood grief, sundered by adult quarrels, Prince William and Prince Harry came together briefly on Thursday to dedicate a statue of their mother, Diana, Princess of Wales, on what would have been her 60th birthday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández and Joy Dong
title: China’s Communist Party Turns 100. Cue the (State-Approved) Music.
description: A wave of nationalistic music, theater and dance is sweeping China, part of Beijing’s efforts to improve the party’s image and strengthen political loyalty.
content: Yan Shengmin, a Chinese tenor, is known for bouncy renditions of Broadway tunes and soulful performances in operas like “Carmen.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
description: A book of contemporary queer photography, sculptures from Ditte Blohm — and more.
content: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir and Elian Peltier
title: Give Africa greater access to buy vaccines, a special envoy urges the European Union.
description: “We are not asking for donations — in fact, we have money to buy vaccines,” said the official, Strive Masiyiwa. “Vaccines are not expensive, certainly when it comes to the lives of our people.”
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — The African Union’s special envoy on Covid-19 urged Europe to relax restrictions on vaccine makers’ exports so that African countries could buy more doses and try to stem a fast-surging third wave of the pandemic driven mainly by the more contagious Delta variant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Our colleague in Auckland describes her lockdown whiplash.
content: Countries across the Asia-Pacific region — including Australia, Malaysia, Indonesia, Hong Kong and Bangladesh — are scrambling to slow the spread of the Delta variant. Many governments are reimposing restrictions. For societies that had just begun to reopen, it’s a jarring reminder that the pandemic is far from over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Leland
title: Is There a Right Way to Act Blind?
description: Activists slammed the TV show “In the Dark” for casting a sighted actress in a blind lead role. But what if blindness is a performance of its own?
content: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers
title: Pictures From a Revolution: China’s Communists Mark a Centennial
description: The improbable rise of a superpower that was born in the rubble of dynasty and fears it may yet meet the same fate.
content: In the summer of 1921, there was nothing inevitable about the Communist Party of China, even its survival. Especially its survival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Rattner
title: Why ‘Amtrak Joe’ Should Pull Back on Train Funding
description: The president wants to pour billions more into a service that makes sense only in a few areas.
content: Ah, the romantic suspense of train travel: Cary Grant and Eva Marie Saint canoodling in “North by Northwest.” Farley Granger and Robert Walker conspiring in “Strangers on a Train.” While long-haul railroads have a beloved place in our history, Americans almost entirely abandoned them more than a half century ago for the greater convenience of cars and the speed of planes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Scouting Groups Report Losing About 1.7 Million Members During Pandemic
description: The Boy Scouts have lost more than half of its members since 2019, while enrollment in the Girl Scouts dropped by 30 percent in one year, the groups estimated.
content: Membership in the Boy Scouts and the Girl Scouts has plunged during the pandemic, according to new enrollment figures released by the youth organizations, which had already been hampered by assorted legal, financial and societal issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Ito
title: ‘We the People’ Updates the Sound of Schoolhouse Rock With Rap and R&B
description: The new animated Netflix series, which counts the Obamas as executive producers, fuses civics lessons with musical contributions from Cordae, Adam Lambert, H.E.R., Lin-Manuel Miranda and many others.
content: How do you create a catchy music video about the Bill of Rights? The source material isn’t the most ear-wormy stuff, with its guidelines on due process and its prohibitions against excessive bail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Cheney Agrees to Join Jan. 6 Inquiry, Drawing Threats of G.O.P. Retribution
description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s decision to offer a slot to the Wyoming Republican was an effort to bring a veneer of bipartisanship to an investigation the G.O.P. has denounced as one-sided.
content: Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Thursday named Representative Liz Cheney of Wyoming to a newly created special committee to investigate the Jan. 6 riot at the Capitol, choosing a Republican who has blamed former President Donald J. Trump for fomenting the assault to help conduct an inquiry that the rest of her party has fought to block at every turn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘The Boss Baby: Family Business’ Review: Pacifier Be With You
description: It’s more of the same in this sequel to the 2017 comedy featuring the voice of Alec Baldwin.
content: Grab your briefcases: The boss baby has returned in “The Boss Baby: Family Business,” directed by Tom McGrath, another infant adventure that hits the same notes as the original, and has little to show for it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: What to Know About the Delta Variant in California
description: Thursday: Los Angeles County public health officials advised wearing masks indoors, but said new restrictions were unlikely.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Krauss
title: New in Paperback: ‘The Pull of the Stars’ and ‘Memorial Drive’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: STRANGER IN THE SHOGUN’S CITY: A Japanese Woman and Her World, by Amy Stanley. (Scribner, 352 pp., $18.) Stanley’s discovery of a 19th-century letter from a Buddhist priest’s daughter who fled her family’s rural village for the city that would soon become Tokyo was the genesis for this 2020 biography, which won the National Book Critics Circle and PEN/Jacqueline Bograd Weld awards.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Catch up: Nikole Hannah-Jones is granted tenure at U.N.C.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich, William K. Rashbaum, Ben Protess and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Was Not Indicted. But the Charges Still Threaten Him.
description: The criminal case against the former president’s business could deliver a blow to his finances, and he remains the focus of a broader investigation in New York.
content: After all the suspicion and anticipation, it was not a conspiracy involving Russia, widespread money laundering or a sweeping allegation of racketeering and corruption.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal and Victor J. Blue
title: A Covid Epicenter Hustles Back to Life: ‘What You See, It’s Survival’
description: The neighborhoods in Queens that reeled during the pandemic are buzzing. But recovery feels very far away.
content: Every day along Roosevelt Avenue in Queens, people stream off the elevated subway into a swarm of activity. Vendors ring bells and shout in Spanish — “Masks! Water! Shaved ice!”— as smoke rises from grilling meat and cumbia music competes with the rumble of the train.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Legal Threats Hover Over Trump as He Hints at a 2024 Bid
description: As the former president weighs another run for the White House, he’s confronting various investigations and lawsuits. Here’s a rundown.
content: Donald Trump hit the campaign trail again last weekend, and he certainly seemed happy to be back in the spotlight. He bashed President Biden and undocumented immigrants, repeated his false claims of a stolen 2020 election, and hinted at a possible run for the presidency again in 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘No Sudden Move’ Review: Don’t Forget the Motor City
description: Don Cheadle and Benicio Del Toro star in Steven Soderbergh’s new film, a Detroit-set period thriller with a lot on its mind.
content: On an ordinary Monday morning in Detroit, three masked men show up at a handsome brick house on a tree-lined street. Once inside, two of them hold a mother and her children at gunpoint while their colleague accompanies the man of the house, a midlevel accountant at General Motors, on an urgent errand. It’s the mid-1950s, which means the cars are big and curvy, the men mostly wear hats and neckties, and the women are mostly wives, secretaries or mistresses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Bare Feet, Beer and Heavy Metal Bangers: Golf Chills Out and Gets Cool
description: Traditional golf is increasingly seen as old and stuck in its ways. But imaginative takes on the sport are making it more fun and attracting new players.
content: Golf is one of the world’s oldest sports, with treasured traditions honed across several centuries. But increasingly over the last decade, many people have come to see golf as just plain old. And not in a good way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: The Rest of the World Is Worried About America
description: When experts from other countries look at "the oldest democracy," they don't like what they see.
content: This weekend, American skies will be aflame with fireworks celebrating our legacy of freedom and democracy, even as Republican legislature after Republican legislature constricts the franchise and national Republicans have filibustered the expansive For The People Act. It will be a strange spectacle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Knowing What Your Co-Worker Makes Doesn’t Close the Pay Gap
description: Salary transparency is intended to help address inequities. But making the number public doesn’t seem to move the needle.
content: Carolyn Kopprasch earns $225,000 a year. Maria Thomas makes $267,890. Then comes Darcy Peters with a salary of $105,143.
source.name: The New York Times

title: We Want to Hear from Afghan War Veterans
description: As the U.S. involvement in Afghanistan draws to a close, The New York Times is asking service members and veterans who served there to share their stories.
content: After nearly two decades of fighting in Afghanistan, the United States is withdrawing all military forces and contractors in the coming weeks — bringing to an end its involvement in a conflict in which nearly 800,000 service members, and countless contractors, served.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Dana Spiotta Loves Coming Across Jokes in Really Old Books
description: “I feel such connection to the human who made it, which delights and moves me. If you can write a joke that is still funny in 100 years, you are great.”
content: “I feel such connection to the human who made it, which delights and moves me,” says the novelist, whose new book is “Wayward.” “If you can write a joke that is still funny in 100 years, you are great.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John I. Jenkins
title: At Notre Dame, We Believe ‘Student’ Should Come First in ‘Student-Athlete’
description: Education has to be the top priority, says University of Notre Dame president John I. Jenkins.
content: We college presidents have learned to tread lightly when it comes to the passions of alumni and other fans for our athletic teams, whether it is one competing for a national championship or a less heralded group playing a rivalry game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: How Dangerous Is the Delta Variant?
description: Having spread to at least 85 countries, the Delta variant is now fueling outbreaks around the world and prompting new lockdowns.
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Greenhouse
title: What the Supreme Court Did for Religion
description: The court has become more open to claims of government regulations impeding religion.
content: After the Supreme Court wraps up its pending business on Thursday, there will be plenty to discuss and debate about a term that seems to have confounded many people’s expectations. I’ll leave that conversation for the coming days. For now, I want to explore one of the week’s overlooked developments for what it might tell us about what happened beneath the surface on a subject of great import this term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aina J. Khan
title: Prominent Women Call for Tech Giants to Act Against Online Harassment
description: The signatories included the tennis champion Billie Jean King, and the actors Thandiwe Newton, Ashley Judd and Emma Watson.
content: More than 200 prominent women from around the world, including actors, journalists, musicians and former government leaders, have written an open letter urging the chief executives of Facebook, Twitter, TikTok and Google to “prioritize the safety of women” on their platforms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Donald Ayer, Norman Eisen and E. Danya Perry
title: Why the Law Is Strong Enough to Take On Donald Trump
description: The ultimate value of the New York investigation is simple: accountability.
content: A 15-count indictment for tax fraud and other charges filed in New York on Thursday against the Trump Organization and its longtime chief financial officer, Allen Weisselberg, has already stimulated as much hand-wringing as satisfaction from those who have called for accountability for Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanne Timmons
title: Shrinking Elephants Once Called Sicily Home
description: New research suggests that in as little as 40 generations, elephants could have become dwarf size on the island off Italy’s boot.
content: Elephants today are confined to the African and Asian continents. But their extinct relatives once roamed far and wide across the planet. When they settled onto islands, some species’ evolutionary course changed direction in a dramatic fashion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: The first open meeting of the F.T.C. under Lina Khan starts with political sparks.
description: Ms. Khan, the agency’s chair, opened with a statement about the importance of transparency, but the two Republican commissioners pushed back on her approach.
content: Lina Khan’s first meeting of the Federal Trade Commission on Thursday revealed political friction and previewed the likely partisan battles to come. Ms. Khan took over as chair last month and made the agency’s monthly meetings open to the public, a major change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley and Keith Bradsher
title: Marking Party’s Centennial, Xi Warns That China Will Not Be Bullied
description: A century after the Communist Party’s founding, China’s leader said foreign powers would “crack their heads and spill blood” if they tried to stop its rise.
content: China’s rise is unstoppable, Xi Jinping declared. The country will not be lectured. And those who try to block its ascent will hit a “Great Wall of steel.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Neil Vigdor
title: 17 Are Wounded After Seized Explosives Blow Up in Los Angeles
description: The explosion happened during what was supposed to be a controlled detonation of improvised explosives that the police had confiscated from a residential property, the authorities said.
content: Seventeen people, including 10 law enforcement officers, were wounded on Wednesday when part of a cache of improvised explosives blew up in South Los Angeles during what was supposed to be a controlled detonation by police bomb squad technicians, the authorities said. One man was taken into custody and charged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen
title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn, Queens and Manhattan
description: This week’s properties are in Boerum Hill, Corona and Carnegie Hill.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Some of Our Stallions’ Review: At Least They Don’t Shoot Horses
description: The film poses the cause-and-effect question about toxic masculinity and unhinged behavior.
content: No equine beasts adorn this queasy comedy. Too bad. The title “Some of Our Stallions,” parodies, one presumes, the self-aggrandizing language certain American males apply to themselves. The would-be “stallions” here are a couple of misfits. Carson Mell, who plays a burly, bearded guy who insists on being addressed as “Beautiful Bill,” wrote and directed the movie and has a starring role alongside Al Di, also a producer, who plays the fast-talking Andy. In the opening scene, Bill, in a fast-food restaurant meltdown, dunks his hands into the hot oil of a deep fryer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: Pandemic Lockdowns Aided Predators Worldwide, Especially Online, U.S. Says
description: The number of cases of online sex exploitation, including of children, appeared to skyrocket last year as people spent more time on computers.
content: WASHINGTON — Predators worldwide took advantage of pandemic restrictions last year to draw more people into forced labor and sex trafficking, including children who spent their days online under government-imposed stay-at-home orders, according to a new State Department report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: Phoenix Suns Headed to First N.B.A. Finals in Almost 30 Years
description: This will be the first trip to the finals for the Suns’ veteran leader, Chris Paul, who scored 41 points in the series-clinching Game 6 victory over the Los Angeles Clippers.
content: The Phoenix Suns, after missing the playoffs for 10 consecutive seasons, are headed to the N.B.A. finals for the first time since 1993.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Indoor smoking returns in Atlantic City casinos on the Fourth of July.
description: Smoking on gambling floors has not been permitted since casinos reopened a year ago because of concerns the exhaled vapor could spread the coronavirus.
content: New Jersey’s yearlong ban on smoking inside casinos in Atlantic City will end on Sunday as the state continues to relax its coronavirus-related mandates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Physically and Mentally Taxed, Olympic Hopefuls Near the Finish
description: The pandemic year disrupted athletes’ training routines, leaving many depressed, anxious and seeking help.
content: EUGENE, Ore. — Sam Parsons felt that he was in the best shape of his life when he lined up for the start of the 5,000 meters at the Drake Relays in April. He had used the yearlong Olympic postponement to ramp up his training with the goal of competing for Germany at the Tokyo Games this summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch and Michael J. de la Merced
title: Krispy Kreme and Didi Chuxing are part of a blockbuster week for public listings.
description: Eighteen initial public offerings hit the stock market this week, making it the busiest since 2004.
content: On any normal week, the trading debuts of Krispy Kreme or Didi Chuxing, the Chinese ride-hailing giant, would be the biggest news in initial public offerings. But they were just two of 18 I.P.O.s that hit the markets this week, making it the busiest since December 2004.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: In ‘Enemy of the People,’ Water and Democracy Are Poisoned
description: Ann Dowd stars in a contemporary rewrite of Ibsen’s play that forces a community, played by the audience, to make a series of fateful choices.
content: Elections in Weston Springs are so simple. When a question comes before the townspeople, they confer in small groups, reach a consensus, press a button marked “X” or “O” and get the result, all within a minute. To a New Yorker, that sounds nice right about now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charly Wilder
title: In Greece, It’s Almost Normal
description: In Athens and on the island of Paros, a visitor joins other international travelers in search of that idyllic European vacation they’ve been yearning for.
content: The plaster-cast heads of Dionysus were back. The unblinking blue Mati evil eyes and Parthenon refrigerator magnets hung once more outside the souvenir shops of Plaka and Monastiraki, where shopkeepers tended to rows upon rows of leather sandals, silver meander rings, dried spices and Cretan mountain tea. The tourists were back, too, if not quite so many as one might expect in the historic heart of Athens on a similarly brilliant, blue June day of years past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annabelle Williams
title: Patricia Reilly Giff, ‘Polk Street’ Children’s Book Writer, Dies at 86
description: Ms. Giff wrote more than 100 books, ranging from an exploration of the Irish potato famine to a humorous series about the antics of second-graders.
content: Patricia Reilly Giff, a prolific children’s book author whose work was driven by the idea that remarkable stories could be spun from the lives of ordinary people, died on June 22 at her home in Trumbull, Conn. She was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The Supreme Court Abandons Voting Rights
description: The Roberts court continues its attack against the Voting Rights Act.
content: The 1965 Voting Rights Act was one of the most important pieces of legislation in American history. By outlawing racial discrimination in voting and imposing federal oversight in states with histories of discriminating, it finally enforced the 15th Amendment and marked the first time the nation could call itself a truly representative democracy. Until the last decade, the law occupied a sacred spot in the American legal system. In 2006, Congress reauthorized the law nearly unanimously.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Curling Locales
description: Joe Deeney makes a deal out of things.
content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Without giving away spoilers, there is a technical issue that may be preventing some solvers who are playing in the iOS and Android apps from seeing the puzzle correctly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: ‘Cousins’ Review: The Ties That Bind
description: This sprawling drama breathes cinematic life into the 1992 novel by Patricia Grace about the diverging paths of three Maori cousins in New Zealand.
content: The Maori family at the heart of “Cousins” greet each other by pressing their foreheads and noses together. The camera does the same: It peers deep into the characters’ faces, as if imprinting them onto its lens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rasha Al Aqeedi
title: Donald Rumsfeld Tore My Country Apart
description: To the extent he set Iraq on a course of destruction, he won’t be forgotten. But for many of us still hoping for a better Iraq, he is irrelevant.
content: In the early hours of April 10, 2003, I had taken refuge in what was — for me — the safest place in the world: the floor of my parents’ bedroom in our home in Mosul, Iraq.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Showing Migrants Through a New Lens: Their Own
description: As many waited on the U.S.-Mexican border, hoping to enter the United States despite the government’s message to stay away, a photographer let them be seen on their own terms.
content: Migrants seeking to enter the United States today find themselves in a difficult position: They have been told by the government not to come, but many feel they need to flee the conditions they face in their home countries. To add context to this complicated issue, the Brooklyn-based freelance photographer Adam Ferguson asked migrants at shelters on the Mexican side of the U.S.-Mexico border to take self-portraits this spring (with some guidance from him), giving them a chance to express themselves visually.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: Stolen Picasso and Mondrian Paintings Found Stashed in a Ravine in Greece
description: Ending a long-running mystery, a construction worker guided the police to the hiding place after admitting he had taken the works in a daring one-man raid on the National Gallery in Athens in 2012.
content: ATHENS — When paintings by Picasso and Mondrian and a sketch by the Italian artist Guglielmo Caccia went missing from the National Gallery in Athens in 2012, it was the beginning of a mystery that lasted for nearly a decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Upholds Arizona Voting Restrictions
description: The decision, a test of what remains of the Voting Rights Act, suggests that challenges to many new measures making it harder to vote may not be successful.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Thursday gave states new latitude to impose restrictions on voting, using a ruling in a case from Arizona to signal that challenges to laws being passed by Republican legislatures that make it harder for minority groups to vote would face a hostile reception from a majority of the justices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Why Didn’t Microsoft Die?
description: Microsoft made epic mistakes for years, but it’s again one of the tech world’s superstars.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: President Biden meets with rescue workers during his visit to Florida.
description: Mr. Biden and his wife, Jill Biden, are scheduled to meet with families of the victims of the condo collapse in Surfside, Fla.
content: President Biden pledged ongoing help from the federal government as he arrived  in Florida Thursday to resume his role as consoler in chief following the collapse of the Champlain Towers South condo building which has left at least 18 people dead and as many as 145 unaccounted for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: Judge Blocks Florida Law Regulating Social Media Companies
description: It would fine companies like Facebook, YouTube and Twitter if they permanently bar candidates for office in the state.
content: A judge on Wednesday blocked a Florida law that would be the first in the nation to prohibit social media companies from barring political candidates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘The Tomorrow War’ Review: Future Schlock
description: Chris Pratt leaps to 2051 to save our planet from aliens in this hyperventilating sci-fi spectacle.
content: It is never good news when a phalanx of armed, balaclava-wearing dudes falls from the sky in the middle of a World Cup soccer game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Restaurant Grant Program Ends in a Cloud of Errors and Confusion
description: More than 100,000 business owners got help from the relief effort, but 265,000 were turned away — some after awards were rescinded.
content: A $28.6 billion federal relief fund for restaurants and other food businesses closed on Wednesday after running out of money, having fulfilled fewer than a third of the grant requests it received.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: Virus Surges in Myanmar, Where Generals Control Vaccines
description: With doctors and other health care workers already on strike to protest the coup, Myanmar’s health care system may buckle under the outbreak.
content: Three days before she was arrested by soldiers, Myanmar’s civilian leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, received her first dose of a coronavirus vaccine. Her high-profile inoculation was part of a nationwide campaign to combat the virus through testing, mask-wearing, lockdowns and vaccination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Precious Fondren
title: Woman Who Falsely Accused Black Teen in SoHo Is Charged With Hate Crime
description: The charges against the woman, Miya Ponsetto, stem from an episode at a New York City hotel where she tackled a teenager who she wrongly said had taken her phone.
content: A California woman who falsely accused a teenager of stealing her phone and then attacked him at a New York City hotel was charged with a hate crime on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing and Eshe Nelson
title: Nissan plans a U.K. battery factory, a lift for the post-Brexit auto industry.
description: The Japanese carmaker will also make a new electric vehicle in England as part of a £1 billion investment, partly supported by the government.
content: The Japanese carmaker Nissan announced plans on Thursday to build a battery factory near its plant in northeastern England, and to manufacture a new electric crossover S.U.V. there, bolstering the chances that Britain’s auto industry can survive Brexit and the transition to electric vehicles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Barbara McQuade
title: There’s One Man to Blame for Bill Cosby’s Release
description: The roots of the Cosby reversal were years in the making.
content: Due process matters, even for monstrous crimes.
source.name: The New York Times

title: After Biden Meets Putin, U.S. Exposes Details of Russian Hacking Campaign
description: The revelations, which dealt with a Russian espionage campaign, came after President Biden demanded that President Vladimir V. Putin rein in more destructive ransomware attacks.
content: WASHINGTON — Two weeks after President Biden met President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and demanded that he rein in ransomware attacks on U.S. targets, American and British intelligence agencies on Thursday exposed the details of what they called a global effort by Russia’s military intelligence organization to spy on government organizations, defense contractors, universities and media companies.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: As Condo Boards Squabble, Disaster May Loom
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, July 1, 2021.
content: “Just because the roof doesn’t send a bill every month doesn’t mean that it doesn’t need to be paid.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘915: Hunting Hispanics’ Review: Anatomy of an American Killing
description: Charlie Minn’s tactical breakdown zeros in on a mass shooting at an El Paso, Texas, Walmart that killed 23 people.
content: On the morning of Aug. 3, 2019, a man armed with an automatic rifle entered a Walmart in El Paso, Texas, shooting 46 people in the span of six minutes. Twenty-three people died as a result of their injuries. Many victims of the El Paso shooting identified as Latino, and in a manifesto, the shooter, Patrick Crusius, had explicitly stated his animus against people of Mexican origin. In the documentary “915: Hunting Hispanics” (the number is the El Paso area code), survivors share their memories of that catastrophic morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff and Margot Sanger-Katz
title: For Surprise Medical Bills, It’s the Beginning of the End
description: Last winter, Congress banned a much-hated practice. Now regulators have to figure out exactly how to make the law work.
content: The Biden administration took its first steps Thursday toward finalizing the details of a ban on surprise medical bills that Congress passed and President Trump signed into law last winter. Some experts see the policy as the most important consumer protection in health care to come out of Washington in more than a decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: Tropical Storm Elsa Forms Over Atlantic
description: The National Hurricane Center issued warnings to several Caribbean islands.
content: Tropical Storm Elsa, the fifth named storm of the 2021 Atlantic hurricane season, formed on Thursday and was projected to deliver dangerous rains and winds to several Caribbean islands on Friday and through the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs
title: Frontline Health Care Workers Aren’t Feeling the ‘Summer of Joy’
description: Doctors and nurses are reeling from new Covid cases, staff burnout and the prolonged stress of dealing with the pandemic.
content: A largely unmasked nation will celebrate the nation’s return to near-normalcy this weekend with a ticker-tape parade in New York City, a dazzling fireworks display over the Washington Monument and countless Independence Day gatherings in cities and towns across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Anheuser-Busch still plans to offer free beer, via gift card, during the July 4 weekend.
description: The White House recently acknowledged that President Biden did not expect to meet his self-imposed deadline of 70 percent of U.S. adults at least partly vaccinated by July 4.
content: Although the White House recently acknowledged that President Biden did not expect to meet his self-imposed deadline of 70 percent of U.S. adults at least partly vaccinated by July 4, Anheuser-Busch still plans to offer to buy much of the United States a beer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane, David E. Sanger and Michael D. Shear
title: ‘We’re Here for You’: Biden Meets With Florida Families Amid ‘Unbearable’ Wait
description: The president said chances were fading that anyone else would be found alive under the mass of concrete and steel left by a collapsed condominium.
content: SURFSIDE, Fla. — President Biden spent three hours Thursday consoling the families of those who died or were still missing under the rubble of a collapsed condominium building near Miami Beach, saying “the waiting is unbearable” for agonized relatives as crews halted a desperate search for much of the day out of concern that the rest of the complex could also fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Canada Goose’s Image Is Challenged by Union Effort
description: Production of the company’s parkas was once fully unionized, but labor organizers say the owners have taken a harder line in recent years.
content: Canada Goose, the luxury jacket maker, has cultivated an image that is not only chic but also socially conscious. It has forged alliances with environmental advocates and talked of its commitment to high labor standards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Bill Cosby’s Release From Prison, Explained
description: Here is breakdown of the legal issues surrounding a Pennsylvania Supreme Court ruling that abruptly let the disgraced entertainer out of prison.
content: The disgraced actor and comedian Bill Cosby walked free this week after three years in prison when the Pennsylvania Supreme Court threw out his 2018 convictions on charges of drugging and sexually assaulting Andrea Constand in 2004, when she was a Temple University employee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Every Shot, and Second, Counts for Tampa Bay
description: The Lightning’s Blake Coleman dived to tip in the winning goal in the final moments of the second period to help Tampa Bay triumph despite being heavily outshot. His move looked awfully familiar.
content: TAMPA, Fla. — It was a cute idea, really it was. This notion that as the final seconds ticked off and play lingered in the neutral zone, the middle period of Game 2 of the Stanley Cup finals would end, just end, with the score still tied but the Montreal Canadiens in control. A puck, though — it can do some wondrous things when manipulated by marvels, and Lightning winger Barclay Goodrow poked it beyond one Montreal defenseman, then maneuvered it past another to whip a backhand pass across the slot, and then there was no time left until there was just enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Wally Funk, Trailblazing Female Pilot, Will Join Jeff Bezos on Spaceflight
description: At 82, Ms. Funk will become the oldest person ever to go to space. In the 1960s, she was part of a test program to determine whether women were fit for space.
content: Mary Wallace Funk, an 82-year-old pilot who was prevented from becoming an astronaut in the 1960s because of her sex, will join Jeff Bezos on his rocket ship company’s first human flight into space, the company announced on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Till Death’ Review: My Relationship is Dragging Me Down
description: Megan Fox leads this straightforward, but gleefully chaotic thriller about a woman handcuffed to the corpse of her husband.
content: In “Till Death,” Megan Fox plays Emma, a glamorous woman who got hitched at an age when she simply didn’t know any better. That’s partly why she’s been having an affair, though she breaks it off in an attempt to make things right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Who Is rg_bunny1: An Instagram Whodunit
description: Doping out the identity of an obsessive, enigmatic Instagram poster has become a favored pastime of the scrolling classes.
content: It is the parlor game of the pandemic. Among a certain segment of the scrolling classes, art and literary division, firing up their tablets and smartphones each morning has taken on aspects of a whodunit. Rifling through Instagram feeds, they register with half yawns the sponsored posts and thirst traps, the Throwback Thursday selfies and banal memes of cats. All the while they are waiting to happen upon the latest clue from a particular account.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Imperial Editor Goes the Way of the Dodo
description: Business and culture have conspired to kill off a passé persona.
content: On Monday, when the fashion world will gather in Paris for the first live couture shows since the pandemic began and assorted editors will take their socially distanced seats en masse, the front row — that power chain of often instantly recognizable individuals who set the tone for trends and style setters for the world — will look very different.

author: By Emily Anthes
title: The Delta variant is not driving a surge in hospitalization rates in England, health data shows.
description: Although the number of coronavirus infections has risen sharply in recent weeks, hospitalization rates remain low.
content: The Delta variant, which is now responsible for most coronavirus infections in England, is not driving a surge in the rate of hospitalizations there, according to data released by Public Health England on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Boryana Straubel, 38, Dies; Founded a ‘Green’ Jewelry Company
description: A former Tesla executive, she ran a family foundation that focuses on environmental sustainability. Her jewelry company uses recycled metals.
content: Boryana Straubel, a philanthropist and advocate for environmental sustainability who founded Generation Collection, a jewelry company that uses recycled metals for its designs, died on June 19 after being struck by a car while riding her bicycle in Washoe County, Nev. She was 38.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Books Are Forever. Best Sellers Are Fleeting.
description: Here’s a look at novels selling like gangbusters in the second week of July, all the way back to 1971.
content: LOOK BACK IN LANGUOR July is a month for retro pleasures — kites, badminton, snow cones and water balloons, to name a few. So why do so many of us reach for books that are hot off the presses? I decided to pay a visit to best-seller lists of yore to find out what shiny penny novels were flying off the shelves 10, 20, 30, 40 and 50 years ago this week.

content: J.D. Vance, an author and venture capitalist whose best-selling memoir, “Hillbilly Elegy,” focused on the social and economic underpinnings of former President Donald J. Trump’s appeal to the white working class, said on Thursday that he would seek the Republican nomination for the Senate in Ohio.

content: Britney Spears has been living under a conservatorship of her person and her estate since 2008, and in recent years, that arrangement has come under increased scrutiny. content: Imagine video gamers, untethered from their computers and consoles, playing crystal-clear versions of their favorite games anywhere. They might traverse the futuristic world of the sci-fi shooter game Halo on their mobile phones while riding the subway, or dust off old MacBook computers and hop straight into the jungle of the battle arena game League of Legends.

title: N.F.L. Penalizes Washington Football Team Amid Harassment Allegations
description: The penalty of a $10 million fine follows an investigation into sexual harassment and abuse in the team’s front office.
content: The N.F.L. on Thursday announced that the Washington Football Team would pay a $10 million fine to the league after a yearlong investigation into reports of the club’s rampant culture of sexual harassment perpetuated by managers and executives under the ownership of Daniel Snyder. The team also must reimburse the league for the cost of the investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

content: “Let Us In,” a kids-fighting-evil movie in the vein of “The Goonies” (1985) and Netflix’s “Stranger Things,” is creepy-cute and cheerfully corny. description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi appointed Representative Liz Cheney, Republican of Wyoming, to a newly created special committee to investigate the Jan. 6 riot at the Capitol. Ms. Cheney’s appointment appeared to be an attempt by Democrats to bring a degree of bipartisanship to the investigation.

title: Joe Rogan Is Too Big to Cancel

description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, July 1, 2021.
content: An article on Wednesday about the decision by Representative James Clyburn of South Carolina to endorse Shontel Brown for Congress misstated which House Democratic leaders had agreed to vacate their posts after this Congress.
